columns.text: In this problem, we will use the market value and book value of the yield to maturity of a certain stock to solve for its weighted average cost of debt.

There are two important values that we need to remember: book value and market value. The book value simply refers to the value that the company declares in their books. On the other hand, the market value is the value of the company as valued by the market.

The yield to maturity refers to the rate of return of a bond when all interest payments and the principal investment has already been paid. In the case of this company, the values are given below:

For the book value:

|Yield to maturity |Book value weight | 
|--|--| 
| 0.0435| 0.375| 
| 0.0392| 0.125| 
| 0.0225| 0.250| 
| 0.0286| 0.250|

From the values above, we can solve for the weighted average cost of debt of the book value of the yield to maturity by first multiplying the yield to maturity by the book value weight then getting the sum.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond 1}&=0.0435 \times 0.375\\
&=0.0163125\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 2}&=0.0392 \times 0.125\\
&=0.0049\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 3}&=0.0225 \times 0.250\\
&=0.005625\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 4}&=0.0286 \times 0.250\\
&=0.00715
\end{aligned}$$

Adding together the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weighted average cost of debt}&=0.0163125+0.0049+0.005625+0.00715\\
&=0.0339875
\end{aligned}$$

The weighted average cost of debt for the book value is $0.0339875$.

For the market value:

|Yield to maturity |Market value weight | 
|--|--| 
| 0.0435| 0.3457| 
| 0.0392| 0.1223| 
| 0.0225| 0.2846| 
| 0.0286| 0.2473|

From the values above, we can solve for the weighted average cost of debt of the market value of the yield to maturity by first multiplying the yield to maturity by the market value weight then getting the sum.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond 1}&=0.0435 \times 0.3457\\
&=0.01503795\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 2}&=0.0392 \times 0.1223\\
&=0.00479416\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 3}&=0.0225 \times 0.2846\\
&=0.0064035\\[15 pt]
\text{Bond 4}&=0.0286 \times 0.2473\\
&=0.00707278
\end{aligned}$$

Adding together the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weighted average cost of debt}&=0.01503795+0.00479416+0.0064035+0.00707278\\
&=0.03331
\end{aligned}$$

The weighted average cost of debt for the market value is $0.03331$.

As we can see from the values above, there is a difference, although not that significant, when using the different values in solving for the weighted average cost of debt.

The reason for the difference is that in the market value, several other factors are taken into consideration which may not have been consider by the company when they declared their book values. Despite this, we can see that the book values and the market values are similar which shows that  the values given by the company are pretty accurate based on how the market values them.
